intro: Calais clevelandii, commonly known as the Cleveland's calais, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its compound leaves and umbel-shaped flower clusters. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and prefers full sun to partial shade. Its flowers are white or pale yellow, and it blooms from spring to early summer. Calais clevelandii is often found in coastal and inland areas, where it contributes to local biodiversity.
